elements.name: question1
elements.title: The environmental impact of packaging is much worse than the food itself.

elements.name: question2
elements.title: Correction:
elements.correctAnswer: The packaging protects the contents. The environmental impact (including CO2 emissions, water consumption and/or use of chemicals) caused by the production of food is usually much greater than the environmental impact caused by the packaging. Nevertheless, attention must of course be paid to reducing unnecessary packaging.

elements.name: question3
elements.title: Disposable glass bottles are better for the environment than PET.

elements.name: question4
elements.title: Correction:
elements.correctAnswer: Melting down glass requires a lot of energy. PET that is recycled can be used several times. PET therefore has a better carbon footprint than disposable glass bottles.

elements.title: In Switzerland, 16,500 hectares of sugar beet are planted for sugar beet cultivation. The large machines take their toll on the soil. This affects 1.8% of the agricultural land. A large proportion of the sugar is used to produce sweet drinks.

elements.title: Around 1000 liters of water are needed to produce 1 kg of cotton.

elements.name: question8

elements.correctAnswer: Depending on the method of collection and calculation, an average of 11,000 liters of water are used to produce 1 kg of cotton. This is in addition to pesticides.

elements.name: question9
elements.title: Drinking a cup of coffee consumes 132 liters of water. This is because such a large amount of water is needed to produce just 7g of coffee.

elements.name: question11
elements.title: So-called fast fashion is not harmful to the environment as it is quickly withdrawn from circulation.

elements.name: question12
elements.title: Correction:
elements.correctAnswer: Fast fashion refers to clothing that is produced in large quantities, bought cheaply and usually only worn for a short time. Some of it has traveled around the world. In some cases, it is exported to another country for each individual production step. The textile industry alone causes more CO2 equivalents than international air and sea traffic combined. Insecticides, pesticides and other chemicals are also used.
